title.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: the name given to a particular book, painting, play etc
title.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The title of this play is ‘Othello’.
title.translation[0].definitions[0].note: In everyday English, people usually say that something is called ..., rather than saying its title is ...:
title.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a name such as ‘Sir’ or ‘Professor’, or abbreviations such as ‘Mrs’ or ‘Dr’, that are used before someone’s name to show their rank or profession, whether they are married etc
title.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a name that describes someone’s job or position
title.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: the position of being the winner of an important sports competition
title.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Tyson won the WBA title in 1987.
title.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: the legal right to have or own something
title.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: He has title to the land.
title.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a name that describes a person’s job or position
title.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Her official title is Human Resources Manager.
title.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a particular book, magazine, piece of software etc sold by a company
title.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: We publish 200 new titles a year.
title.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: the legal right to own property
title.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: You must demonstrate that you have proof of title.
Who holds the title to the land?
